newsitem.title: FRANCE: EU firms book 100,000 T wheat export for Africa.
newsitem.headline: EU firms book 100,000 T wheat export for Africa.

text.p: European grain firms have taken up export licences for 100,000 tonnes of wheat to a target group of African importing countries, subsidised at 12 Ecus per tonne and valid until the end of February, French grain officials said.
The licences were booked on Friday and Monday after the European Union announced on Thursday a fixed refund of 12 Ecus per tonne for a group of African nations needing special aid.
They fall under an EU scheme to offer licences through its daily export channel and which are valid for the standard current month plus four months, the officials said.
The list of destinations targeted by the refunds -- which are some five Ecus over latest ordinary refunds -- has not been published, but French officials said 38 countries were involved.
Nigeria, a traditional destination for the United States, is excluded.
The European Commission has three working days to use right of veto over the licence applications.
Officials had no details on the progress of a second targeted export scheme, which allows licences to remain valid until the end of the season on June 30 next year.
This regime is drawn up on so-called Article Nine provisions which force traders to show contracts before getting licences.
The special refunds of 12 Ecus per tonne will be upgraded to 19 Ecus per tonne from January through a procedure known as a positive corrective, EU officials said last week.
